title: Scenario rhymes with Cheerio, which is good thing, especially considering my addict-like dependence upon those scrumptious little toasted O's.
body:
So I've been thinking, "what would really happen if the Moxie went bust?" As much as I hate to consider this option, it's something that every business owner, large or small, needs to do from time to time. Develop an exit strategy.

As you may recall, both Nicole’s and my parents have been gracious enough to act as guarantors for our loans, which relieves a lot of the stress of having our loan approved. On the flip side, their involvement also adds a certain amount of pressure that having a less emotionally-involved investor would not. If the Moxie goes down in flames, the last thing I want to happen is for my family to get pulled down with it. Regardless of who guarantees or co-signs the loan, I want the burden of success to fall squarely upon my shoulders.

Now, with that being said, let’s look at the numbers:

Believe it or not, our loan is not much more than what we’d be borrowing if Nicole and I were purchasing our first home. Here’s how the numbers break down:

1. Equipment - $35,000
2. Working capital - $15,000
3. Everything else - $25,000

That brings our total loan package to $75,000, which, after our initial capital injection of $10,000, will drop to $65,000. Our monthly loan repayment will be somewhere between $1,100 and $1,400, which is roughly the cost of a nice apartment in a large city (with the exception of San Francisco and New York City, where upside-down laundry baskets typically rent for as high as $2,000 to $2,500 per month).

So, let’s assume we pay back $13,000 over the course of our first year and then go bust. We sell our equipment back to the vendor at a little less than 50% depreciation ($17,000), and now we’re looking at a loan repayment of $35,000, which we can either refinance or continue paying at our predetermined payments and finish a year or two earlier than our planned seven year term. Either way, our rent is cheap enough in Springfield that it shouldn’t be too difficult for Nicole and I to find jobs and pay off the remainder over the course of next 3 to 4 years. Once the loan is paid off, we move on with our lives. Simple as that.

We may have to live like peasants while we’re paying back the loan, but that’s the cost you have to pay to follow your dreams. How LAME did that sound. Of course, all of this is a moot point since we’re going to be spectacularly successful, I’m going to pen three novels and five screenplays during my downtime, and then we’re going to sell the Moxie to Landmark theatres and retire to Iceland. Yippee!
author: Dan
